channel.title: Comments on: How To Become A Tennis Coach
channel.description: Your secret weapon on the court.

item.title: By: Antonio
item.dc:creator: Antonio
item.description: It's obvious this guy just wants to sell his book. He has a general idea but I would recommend getting a legitimate certification from either USPTR or USPTA. Either one is cool. One is more prevalent on the West Coast but they're similar and there's talk of them unifying to better fight the greedy tennis clubs that exploit tennis professionals [not a lot of benefits or health care, they take a huge cut of your lesson fee]. However, once yet get certified, which includes liability insurance, you're good to go until you take further training to show that you keep up with the latest trends and knowledge. Good luck!

item.title: By: George Berteska
item.dc:creator: George Berteska
item.description: I'm very interested in learning to teach tennis for a part-time income. I currently have one student, however, I do not charge him anything. I'm hesitant to bring up the issue of money since he's only 15 years old, and I'm unsure of his parents financial status. As for myself, I've played tennis for the last 43 years and have attained a solid 4.5 level, and at age 62, I feel I am playing the best tennis of my life.
